importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on this date, indicating the most current developments in the case involving James Comey's defense strategy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline reflects the ongoing legal and political controversy surrounding James Comey's prosecution, which began in late September 2025 and continues through the present.

keyTakeAways: James Comey, former FBI Director, is facing criminal charges for allegedly lying during congressional testimony.
Comey’s defense claims the prosecution is a personal vendetta by President Donald Trump, citing a pattern of public attacks on Comey.
Comey’s legal team argues that the appointing of Lindsey Halligan as interim U.S. Attorney violated the Appointments Clause of the Constitution by bypassing Senate confirmation.
The appointment of Halligan occurred after the 120-day limit for interim appointments had expired, which the legal team claims renders the appointment unlawful.
Comey’s attorneys reference the dismissal of Trump’s own indictment in Florida as precedent, arguing that similar unlawful appointments invalidate such prosecutions.
The defense seeks to dismiss the case on grounds of selective and vindictive prosecution and illegal prosecutorial appointments.
Comey has pleaded not guilty to charges of providing false statements and obstructing a congressional proceeding.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former FBI Director James Comey is launching a legal defense against federal charges of providing false statements and obstructing a congressional proceeding, arguing that the prosecution is a politically motivated retaliation by President Donald Trump. His legal team contends that Trump’s personal attacks on Comey and his appointment of interim U.S. Attorney Lindsey Halligan—after the 120-day limit for interim appointments expired—constitute an unconstitutional circumvention of Senate confirmation requirements. The defense claims Halligan’s appointment was illegal, citing precedent from a dismissed Trump indictment involving special counsel Jack Smith, and argues that the case is a selective, vindictive prosecution targeting someone who criticized the president. The case has drawn significant public and legal attention due to its implications for executive power, constitutional appointments, and protected speech.
title: James Comey launches major efforts to have case thrown out
